channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: A realtor said she’d take out an ad to help me rent my New York City apartment. Am I now morally obligated to use her?
item.description: “Other agents know our apartment is available for rent and now want to show it.”

item.title: Stock buyback programs surge in popularity in 2024, despite 1% tax
item.description: Buybacks are popular in a hot stock market and despite concerns about a potential increase to the 1% buyback tax

item.title: Medicare open-enrollment will be a doozy this year. Here’s how to make smart choices.
item.description: Read plan details carefully, and expect changes to prices and coverage.

item.title: You’re not upper class in America until you’ve reached this coveted status
item.description: It may be financial security — more than income level — that characterizes the upper class

item.title: How Long Can the U.S. Economy's 'Goldilocks' Moment Last?
item.description: Markets seem pleased with a strong jobs reading, but significant risks remain.

item.title: Why are nonprofit employee credit unions spending members’ money on stadium naming rights?
item.description: If nonprofit credit unions act like big commercial banks, they should be regulated like them.

item.title: Talk to Rick, the Next CEO of Charles Schwab
item.description: Rick Wurster, Schwab’s president since 2021, will be tasked with steering the largest publicly traded U.S. brokerage through a transition.

item.title: The Score: Stellantis, Nike, Spirit Airlines and More Stocks That Defined the Week
item.description: Here are some of the major companies whose stocks moved on the week’s news.

item.title: The WSJ Dollar Index Rises 0.5% to 97.23
item.description: The WSJ Dollar Index was up 0.5% to 97.23 — up for five consecutive trading days.

item.title: One Small-Stock Fund Crashes the Big-Tech Party
item.description: Hood River fund places No. 6, the outlier among the large-cap funds whose heady gains have been driven by the ‘Magnificent Seven.’
